Description: Fragment of a marble Ionic cyma without Astragal showing remains of the ‘egg’ belonging to inner side a leaf. Traced of blue and red paint was found on the object. The light grey marbled piece is highly weathered and chipped.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Attributed by Petrie to the 'second temple of Apollo'.)
Curator's comments: This fragment belongs together with B 413 and B 414 to an Ionic cyma with thick, fleshy shaped leaves on a deep-lying relief ground. Adjoining the fragment with B 414 the width of the axis as well as the height of the cyma is, though not precisely, reconstructible. The jointed cyma presumably belongs to the corner pieces B 426, B 407, B 409 (reconstruction see Koenigs 2007, 333), however, the profile of the main corner piece differs on its lower ending. Published (Koenigs 2007, 330f. Cat. 19; Petrie 1886, 14 No. 18, Pl. 14 A; L. Shoe 1936, 17 Pl. 6/14 (reconstructed); Altekamp 137 No. 1, Fig. 123).
Bibliographic references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum (B412)
Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (Cat. no.19, p.330-1, pl. 17, 19)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.28) (Phase 3)
